node.text:
VIDEO CASE⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
BRAIN METASTASES⁣
👨🏽‍💻This case is all about being able to tell the difference between cytotoxic and vasogenic oedema. Let’s look at each in turn:⁣
⁣
VASOGENIC OEDEMA⁣
▫️blood-brain barrier disrupted⁣
▫️mainly affects white matter giving finger like pattern⁣
▫️seen predominantly with space occupying lesions such as tumour or abscess⁣
⁣
CYTOTOXIC OEDEMA⁣
▫️blood-brain barrier intact⁣
▫️Na+/K+ pumps fail to operate⁣
▫️Na+ accumulation within cells leading to water being drawn in⁣
▫️leads to ionic oedema with extracellular water accumulation seen as low attenuation within both grey and white matter on CT⁣
▫️loss of grey-white matter differentiation on CT⁣
▫️seen with ischaemic stroke⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻In this case we can see diffuse low density affecting just the white matter - diffuse vasogenic oedema. This should then alert you to the possibility of space occupying lesions which you just make out without IV contrast. Once we give the contrast we can then see multiple ring enhancing lesions⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Malignancy and infection make up the vast majority of peripherally enhancing brain lesions and diffusion weighted MRI is really helpful in trying to tell the difference between abscess and cancer. Abscesses usually light up on DWI given that pus restricts the movement of water molecules whereas this is less the case with malignancy⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻In this case there was a background of breast cancer and the metastases all resolved on giving chemotherapy with remission maintained several years down the line⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
✅Patient consent obtained ⁣
⁣
——-⁣
⁣

⁣
———-⁣

node.text:
VIDEO CASE⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
COVID-19 PNEUMONIA AND SUSPECTED MYOCARDITIS⁣
👨🏽‍💻Chest X-Ray findings can vary - it can be normal in mild cases or early disease but those presenting to hospital will commonly show bilateral peripheral consolidation. This can progress to diffuse consolidation and an ARDS pattern⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻The pattern in this case can be referred to the ‘reverse bat wing’, ie the opposite of the bat wing pattern you see in pulmonary oedema where you get central consolidation ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻What is not common in COVID-19?⁣
▫️Small nodules⁣
▫️Pleural effusions ⁣
▫️Enlarged mediastinal nodes⁣
▫️Cavitating lesions ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Although chest X-Ray can be suggestive remember it is not specific - remember RT-PCR is much more specific (although not completely sensitive). Identical X-rays to this can also be seen in inflammatory conditions such as eosinophilic pneumonia and vasculitis ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Imaging rationales vary across the world - in the UK, the British Society of Thoracic Imaging do not recommend CT as an initial diagnostic tool partly due to problems with exposing the scanner and staff. CXR however does have a role in initial work up ⁣
⁣
▫️Good luck to all healthcare professionals across the world dealing with the COVID-19 pandemic⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣

👍Patient consent obtained

node.text:
VIDEO CASE

PULMONARY OEDEMA/DILATED CARDIOMYOPATHY
👨🏽‍💻The initial X-ray has the classic ‘bat wing’ oedema pattern - commonly seen in acute pulmonary oedema. It is worth bearing in mind that there is a differential for this appearance. Remember the presence of consolidation on an X-ray simply means the alveoli are being filled - this can happen in infection, heart failure, pulmonary haemorrhage and lung cancer

👨🏽‍💻It is the pattern of consolidation and the ancillary findings that help us pick these apart on an X-ray. Central bilateral consolidation is commonly seen in acute pulmonary oedema - compare this with COVID where the pattern is more bilateral PERIPERHAL consolidation

👨🏽‍💻In this case we can also see ‘Kerley B lines’ - horizontal thin lines at the lung bases which helps us decide this is pulmonary oedema. Now remember not all pulmonary oedema is cardiogenic, in this case we can go back to a previous CT and see that the left ventricle was dilated making us more sure that this is cardiogenic pulmonary oedema

👨🏽‍💻The most common cause of LV dysfunction worldwide is ischaemic heart disease. The cardiac MRI in this case helps us by excluding ischaemic heart disease as a cause for the dilated LV. With an ischaemic cardiomyopathy we may expect ‘subendocardial’ (ie the inner part of the myocardium) or transmural enhancement on late gadolinium images whereas in this case we have no enhancement

👨🏽‍💻The underlying diagnosis in this case is dilated cardiomyopathy which was deemed idiopathic. Other causes include prior myocarditis, thyrotoxicosis , alcohol and chemotherapy agents

▫️Hopefully this case will help you to recognise acute pulmonary oedema the next time you see it 

🔻@theradiologistpage

node.text:
CHEST X-RAY REVIEW AREAS IN ONE MINUTE⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Check out this one minute video where I show all the review areas I go through every time I look at a Chest X-Ray⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Using a system is so important when it comes to not missing subtle findings that completely change the diagnosis. When training in radiology I found this really difficult to stick to and it’s taken years of practice to have the mental discipline to go through the same routine every time I look at a Chest X-Ray⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Some X-Rays may have an obvious abnormality - in which case I find it best to assess the problem then go through all the review areas to make sure there isn’t a further problem which may change the diagnosis. Don’t get caught out by satisfaction of search!⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻I’m not saying this is the only way to look at a chest X-ray - it’s best for you to make your own system that is personal to you. Hopefully this can give you some ideas on how to create your own system!⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
——⁣

node.text:
Read on for tips I use when I look at an abdominal CT...⁣⁣
⁣⁣
👨🏽‍💻Coming into radiology as someone who was mainly concerned with what was going on above the diaphragm I found the world of abdominal CT fairly daunting. But by getting to grips with the anatomy of the abdomen things became a whole lot clearer ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
👨🏽‍💻At this level of the abdomen we get a nice demonstration of the superior mesenteric artery – we can’t see the superior mesenteric vein here but normally the vein should lie to the right of the artery at the level of the pancreas, if this is reversed then consider intestinal malrotation which can predispose to midgut volvulus⁣⁣
⁣⁣
👨🏽‍💻I always check to see there is a clean layer of fat surrounding the SMA – if this is infiltrated consider a malignant pathology such as a pancreatic tumour⁣⁣
⁣⁣
👨🏽‍💻Always follow the vessels no matter which CT it is you’re looking at, be it head, neck, chest or abdomen. I always follow the portal veins within the liver formed at the confluence by the splenic vein (which runs posterior to the pancreas) and the superior mesenteric vein which runs vertically. In patients with liver cirrhosis and pancreatitis in particular you are looking for a filling defect or occluded vessel representing thrombosis⁣⁣
⁣⁣
👨🏽‍💻There aren’t many retroperitoneal structures that cross the midline but the left renal vein is one of them – characteristically this passes anterior to the aorta from the left kidney to the IVC but in some people this can have a retroaortic course where it passes behind the aorta. I have seen the occasional incidental left renal vein thrombosis so it is worth checking for filling defects! This is a must in cases of renal cell carcinoma which likes to spread into the IVC via the renal veins⁣⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Did you spot the splenunculus? This is a small nodule made up of accessory splenic tissue. How do we tell the difference between a malignant nodule? This should have identical contrast enhancement to the spleen⁣
⁣⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage

node.text:
The number of CT scans radiology departments are doing around the world is going up year on year⁣
⁣
Why?⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Although CT scans involve more radiation than X-Ray, MRI and ultrasound, the reason we do so much CT is that it is a fantastic test. It’s relatively quick to perform and is good at excluding a wide range of serious pathologies ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻The increased number of requests are a real challenge for radiology departments around the world. How do we a) do the scans and b) get them reported? Although the scans can take minutes to perform, complex CT can take much longer for a radiologist to report⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻As a radiologist it is easy to feel the pressure of the large number of scans that need to be reported. On a personal level I ensure I try to give each scan the time it deserves and don’t deviate from my systems. Any time those systems aren’t followed I know I’m in trouble...⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻It is inevitable that artificial intelligence will have a big role to play in radiology not just in reporting but in the technology in actually performing the scans. For me it is something that will help radiologists alleviate the reporting burden rather than something that will be a ‘threat’ as such. I know many disagree with this but to me the future of radiology is exciting...⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
⁣
———-⁣
⁣

node.text:
Imaging a beating heart...⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
CARDIAC MRI FOUR CHAMBER VIEW⁣
👨🏽‍💻We’ve had a look at the 3 chamber view,  now let’s have a look at the ‘4 chamber view’ on cardiac MRI - this ‘cine’ image gives us a view of the right and left atria and both ventricles, hence the term ‘four chamber’⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻We can identify the left ventricle by its thick wall - on this image we can assess the septal and lateral walls as well as the apex. We can look to see if there is any poor movement of the LV wall which may be induced by iscahemia - we are checking to see all of the LV wall contracts in sync. If one part of the wall does not move it can give a clue that there is a stenosis within one of the coronary arteries, for example a hypokinetic lateral wall may be a sign of left circumflex disease and a poorly moving LV septum can be a sign of left anterior descending artery disease ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻We can also check the right ventricle which is the most anterior heart chamber. Check out the ‘moderator band’ - a muscular band of fibrous tissue that attaches at the septum and which tells us this is the right ventricle (especially helpful in congenital heart disease where the ventricles can be difficult to classify)⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻As well as commenting on chamber size, this view also gives us a nice view of the mitral and tricuspid valves - we can say if there is any stenosis or whether there is a jet of blood coming back into the atrium suggesting regurgitation ⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
———⁣
⁣
#theradiologist #radiology #radiologist #physician #physicianassistant #medicine #medstudent #medicalstudent #medschool #medicalschool #radtech #mri #medical #radiography #radiologystudent #doctor #medicalstudents #interventionalradiology #cardiacmri #surgeon #medic #frcr #cardiology #nursepractitioner #usmle #medlife #exams #premed

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by theRadiologist on September 07, 2021. May be an image of xray and text that says 'L Swipe Male 20s haemoptysis left for explanation theRadiologist'.

node.text:
Have a look at the film then swipe left and read on for the answer…⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
TUBERCULOSIS⁣
👨🏽‍💻This is a tricky case - there was a clear abnormality at the right hilum with consolidation in the right mid zone but the more subtle findings were:⁣
▫️Consolidation extending behind the right heart shadow - remember to look behind the heart, the density should be roughly equal on both sides ⁣
▫️Well defined apical opacity - compare both apices and look between the ribs, here there was an opacity on the right ⁣
▫️Left lower rib erosion - follow all of the ribs! Sometimes a subtle rib erosion can be the only abnormality on the film ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻These findings could represent either a primary lung cancer or TB - given the age of the patient TB is the most likely diagnosis here. The diagnosis was confirmed with positive sputum culture⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Sometimes TB can be more difficult to diagnose as all cultures come back as a false negative - if the sputum was negative here, the patient may have needed bronchoscopy or biopsy of a rib lesion to confirm the diagnosis ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻In TB the aetiology of haemoptysis varies from patient to patient but possibilities for large volume haemoptysis include aneurysms/pesudoaneurysms of the pulmonary arteries (termed Rasmussen’s aneurysm when associated with a cavity) as well as the bronchial arteries as is the case here⁣
⁣
🔻Hopefully you found this case useful - it serves as a good reminder to not get distracted by the obvious abnormality but always keep your review areas in mind!⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
✅Patient consent obtained ⁣
——⁣

node.text:
THORACIC VERTEBRA ANATOMY ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻No CT review is complete without a systematic review of the bones. There are scans I’ve reported where the only abnormality is a lytic lesion affecting a posterior element which without a systematic review would have been missed⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻I like to review all bones thoroughly on axial slices before reviewing on sagittal and coronal slices. For the spine I zoom right up and firstly follow all the vertebrae on bone windows as I scroll down before looking at all of the posterior elements as I scroll back up ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Then comes a really important bit: I go onto soft tissue windows and scroll through again, particularly looking at the spinal canal and neural foramina. It’s important to realise that just looking on bone windows means you may miss soft tissue invading the spinal canal or within the paravertebral region⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻There are twelve thoracic vertebrae which are larger than the cervical vertebrae and more ‘heart shaped’. The laminae, transverse processes and spinous processes of the thoracic vertebrae are all larger than the cervical vertebrae. Identifying the first thoracic vertebra on CT is fairly straightforward: look for the level where the first rib arises ⁣
⁣
🔻It’s really tempting to skip through reviewing the bones on CT, particularly as most people look at the bones last and have already made their mind up about what the scan shows. It’s important to stop yourself doing this and be robotic about reviewing everything in the same manner every time you look at a scan ⁣
⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣

node.text:
ANSWER: Have a look at the X-Ray then swipe left and read on for the explanation….⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
POSTERIOR MEDIASTINAL MASS⁣
👨🏽‍💻There’s a really subtle but important finding on this X-Ray - an extra contour overlying the right side of the mediastinum that can’t be explained by the SVC or the right atrium⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻With older patients the vessels can become ectatic meaning the anatomy may look a little distorted but in a young patient you really need to be able to explain every contour that you can see within the mediastinum. This is why knowing the normal anatomy and looking for it every time is so important when looking at a frontal chest X-ray!⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻As the contour overlies the right main bronchus we know it must lie within the anterior or posterior mediastinum. The CT scan shows us a posterior mediastinal mass. Let’s think about the differential for a posterior mediastinal lesion on X-ray:⁣
▫️Paravertebral lesions: paravertebral abscess, neurogenic tumour, extramedullary haematopoiesis⁣
▫️Oesophageal: hiatus hernia, duplication cyst ⁣
▫️Aortic: aneurysmal descending thoracic aorta ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻In some cases you may get a clue that a lesion is posterior mediastinal as you will lose the contour of other posterior mediastinal structures such as the vertebrae. However in this case you don’t get that sign⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻This lesion turned out to be a neuroblastoma which was successfully treated - you can see on a follow up chest X-ray that the extra contour is no longer present ⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻This is a really tricky one so wouldn’t beat yourself up if you didn’t spot it on a smartphone - the learning point is to always assess the mediastinum systematically on a frontal chest X-ray!⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
☑️Patient consent obtained ⁣

node.text:
Have a look at these coronal images from a post contrast CT and then swipe left and read on for the explanation⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
⁣
AUTOSOMAL DOMINANT POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE (ADPKD)⁣
👨🏽‍💻The CT shows a large number of simple cysts within both kidneys. Once you see this many cysts you have to consider autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease which is a medical exam favourite⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻 Mutations in the PKD1 (85% of cases) and PKD2 (15%) genes lead to this disease where progressive growth of cysts leads to decline in renal function, meaning many go on to need renal replacement therapy. This is the case here with a transplant kidney within the right iliac fossa. Cysts can also be found in the liver which we can also see⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻There are many things associated with ADPKD including:⁣
▫️cerebral aneurysms⁣
▫️bicuspid aortic valve ⁣
▫️mitral valve prolapse⁣
▫️aortic dissection⁣
▫️hypertension⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Although the chance of a renal cell carcinoma arising in one of these cysts is low, on imaging it is important to look through all cysts, looking for any suspicious lesion with a soft tissue component. With CT, it may be necessary to acquire both non contrast and post contrast images to look for a suspicious enhancing component to a cyst⁣
⁣
@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
———-⁣
⁣

node.text:
PELVIC MRI ANATOMY⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Here’s an annotated coronal image from a male pelvic MRI⁣
⁣
👨🏽‍💻Take a look at:⁣
⁣
▫️the iliac and psoas major muscles which join to form the iliopsoas muscle whose insertion we can see at the lesser trochanter of the femur. The iliopsoas is key in hip flexion⁣
⁣
▫️the adductor muscles - we can see some of the adductor muscles here, these pull the legs together and help to stabilise the hip joint. They mainly insert on the medial surface of the femur ⁣
⁣
▫️two of the gluteal muscles which originate at the ilium and insert onto the femur. The larger gluteus maximus muscle is more posterior to this level⁣
⁣
▫️vastus lateralis - which makes up part of the quadriceps femoris within the thigh⁣
⁣
🔻@theradiologistpage⁣
⁣
——-⁣
